title: 115_s1409
content: The Act titled "Technologies for Energy Jobs and Security Act of 2017" extends and phases out residential energy efficient property. The Act "Technologies for Energy Jobs and Security Act of 2017" extends and phases out residential energy efficient property by amending the Internal Revenue Code to extend the deadline to December 31, 2021, and adjust the applicable percentage for energy credits. The Act extends and adjusts energy credits for geothermal and solar/thermal energy properties under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act extends and adjusts energy credits for geothermal and solar/thermal energy properties under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include adding "and geothermal" to the heading, adjusting subparagraphs, and phasing out the 30-percent credit rate for fiber-optic solar, qualified fuel cell, and qualified small wind energy property. The Act extends energy credits for geothermal and solar/thermal properties under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It adjusts credit rates for qualified fuel cell and small wind energy property construction timelines. Amendments also include extending qualified fuel cell property provisions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend various energy credits for geothermal, solar/thermal, microturbine, combined heat and power system, and small wind energy properties. Construction timelines are adjusted to begin before January 1, 2022. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on January 1, 2017. SEC. 4. WASTE HEAT TO POWER PROPERTY. Section 48 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include waste heat to power property as a qualifying property for generating electricity through heat recovery. The amendment to Section 48 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the inclusion of waste heat to power property as a qualifying property for generating electricity through the recovery of a qualified waste heat resource. The construction of such property must begin before January 1, 2022. A qualified waste heat resource includes exhaust heat or flared gas from an industrial process not primarily for electricity production, as well as a pressure drop in any gas for an industrial or commercial process. The amendment allows waste heat to power property to qualify for generating electricity from a qualified waste heat resource, with a capacity limit of 50 megawatts. The effective date for these amendments is before January 1, 2022. The amendments made by this section apply to periods after December 31, 2016, in taxable years ending after that date.
